Pompeo: U.S. to hold Khashoggi killers accountable while maintaining U.S.-Saudi 'strategic relationship'
paragraph:
Secretary of State Mike Pompeo touted efforts the U.S. has already taken to punish Saudi officials implicated in Jamal Khashoggi’s death. | Brendan Smialowski/Pool Photo via AP
Foreign Policy
                    By DAVID BEAVERS11/04/2018 10:33 AM ESTSecretary of State Mike Pompeo pledged on Sunday to hold accountable those responsible for the murder of Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi, while maintaining the important "strategic relationship” between the U.S. and Saudi Arabia.Addressing the Saudi-acknowledged killing of Khashoggi in its consulate in Istanbul last month, Pompeo vowed on “Fox News Sunday” to "hold all of those responsible for the murder” accountable.Story Continued Below“We will do that … at the same time while assuring the strategic relationship between the United States and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.”Pompeo touted efforts the State Department has already taken to punish Saudi officials implicated in Khashoggi’s death.“We’ve revoked visas from 16 individuals that we have been able to identify so far that were in fact connected to that,” Pompeo said.The secretary of state also stressed the importance of the U.S.-Saudi relationship in countering Iran's influence in the region, a Trump administration priority.Earlier, he bluntly labeled Iran "the world’s largest state sponsor of terror."Missing out on the latest scoops?
